content: You’re confusing customers paying for the product (song, story, etc) with customers paying the distributor (streaming service, micropayment interface on your blog, etc). Long before the internet existed, the same problem occurred only it was much worse (look up“payola” on a search engine). I’m not confusing anything with anything. I’m saying exactly this. That people are paying the distributor and not for the product. I think I made that quite clear. Today, it’s actually easier to get paid directly for your work. I’m a “creative” and I do it all the time. And I damn sure don’t charge 10 cents for something that took me an hour (or more!) to create. I can’t speak for Drake or whomever, but most famous musicians make most of their money on concerts and merchandise, not streams and royalties. Why? Because their customers aren’t paying the distributor. The ONLY reason to have a distributor is to increase “brand awareness”, not to make money (directly). Yes it is easier. But it’s a fuck tonne harder to get paid at volume, to get paid over a long period of time, and to find exposure to any audience who wants to pay. Also — it’s an awful lot harder for a writer or an artist to get paid for playing concerts. And even if they did, they’re still not being paid for their creative work, they’re being paid for their personal appearance and that’s not the same thing. Also, quit complaining about being criticized. If people went to all the trouble to write you and call you a “sell out” then at least they care. Far worse to be ignored. If you want to tell me to quit complaining, you can find somebody else’s blog to comment on.
